Test Case Title: As a Nurse, I want to access digitized patient assessments and care plans so that I can efficiently review patient information and update vitals.
Step Action: I am logged into the Clinician Portal. | I search for a patient's record.
Step Expected: I can view digitized assessments and care plans for that patient.
Epic: Digitize patient records and automate tracking.

Test Case Title: As a Doctor, I want to access patient data through the clinician portal so that I can review patient information efficiently.
Step Action: I am logged into the clinician portal. | I search for and select a patient.
Step Expected: I can view the patient's data, including scanned documents and session information.
Epic: Replace Trillium's current system with a new system including database, clinician portal, and session application.

Test Case Title: As a Doctor, I want to access patient clinical information in the clinician portal so that I can efficiently review patient data and make informed decisions.
Step Action: the Doctor is logged into the clinician portal. | the Doctor searches for a specific patient.
Step Expected: the Doctor should be able to view the patient's clinical information, including relevant documents and related data.

Test Case Title: As a Doctor, I want to access and view patient data quickly and efficiently through the clinician portal, so that I can make informed decisions about patient care.
Step Action: I am logged into the clinician portal. | I search for a patient.
Step Expected: I can view the patient's relevant clinical information and documents in an organized manner.

Test Case Title: As a Doctor, I want to access and view patient data quickly and efficiently through the clinician portal, so that I can make informed decisions about patient care.
Step Action: I am viewing a patient's record. | I navigate to different sections of the record (e.g., vitals, medications, history).
Step Expected: The information loads quickly and is presented in a clear and understandable format.

Test Case Title: As a Patient, I want to check in to Day Health and specific sessions using a fingerprint scanner, so that I can easily verify my attendance.
Step Action: I am a patient at Day Health and have a scheduled session. | I use the fingerprint scanner at check-in.
Step Expected: My attendance for Day Health and the specific session is automatically recorded.

Test Case Title: As a system, I want to store previous states of all tables with all changes made to them so that data can be recovered and audited.
Step Action: A table in the database has been modified | The system saves the changes
Step Expected: The previous state of the table is stored along with the changes made.

Test Case Title: As a Patient, I want to sign in for the day using a fingerprint scanner, so that my attendance is recorded accurately.
Step Action: I am a patient arriving for the day. | I use the fingerprint scanner.
Step Expected: My attendance is recorded in the system.

Test Case Title: As a Patient, I want to sign out for the day so that my attendance is accurately recorded.
Step Action: I am a patient in the system. | I sign out for the day.
Step Expected: My sign-out time is stored in the system.

Test Case Title: As a Patient, I want to sign in for sessions, so that my attendance is recorded.
Step Action: I am a patient scheduled for a session | I use the fingerprint scanner
Step Expected: the system records my attendance for the session

Test Case Title: As a Facilitator, I want to confirm session attendance taken through fingerprint scanner so that I can ensure accurate records of patient participation.
Step Action: The system has recorded session attendance via fingerprint scanner. | I access the session attendance records.
Step Expected: I can confirm the attendance data is accurate.

Test Case Title: As a Clinician, I want to store new documents in the database, so that I can maintain a comprehensive record of patient information.
Step Action: I am a logged-in Clinician. | I upload a new patient document.
Step Expected: The document is successfully stored in the database, adhering to HIPAA and FDA 21 CFR Part 11 constraints.

Test Case Title: As a Clinician, I want to add a patient's care plan so that I can manage and track their treatment effectively.
Step Action: I am logged in as a Clinician. | I add a new care plan for a patient.
Step Expected: The care plan is stored in the system and linked to the patient's record.

Test Case Title: As a Doctor, I want to store patient care plans so that I can easily access and manage them within the system.
Step Action: The doctor is logged into the system and has selected a patient. | The doctor creates or updates a patient care plan.
Step Expected: The system should store the care plan securely in the database, adhering to HIPAA regulations.

Test Case Title: As a Doctor, I want to track reviews of care plans so that I can ensure patient care plans are regularly evaluated and updated.
Step Action: A care plan exists for a patient. | A doctor reviews the care plan.
Step Expected: The system records the review date and the doctor who performed the review.

Test Case Title: As a Doctor, I want to track approval of care plans so that I can ensure proper authorization and adherence to treatment protocols.
Step Action: A care plan exists for a patient | The care plan is submitted for approval
Step Expected: The system should record the approval status, approver, and timestamp.

Test Case Title: As a Doctor, I want to store care plan updates and changes so that the patient's EHR is up-to-date.
Step Action: The doctor has made updates to a patient's care plan | The doctor saves the updated care plan
Step Expected: The system stores the care plan updates and changes in the database.

Test Case Title: As a Doctor, I want to store tracks so that I can monitor patient progress and outcomes.
Step Action: The system is running and accessible. | I input track data for a patient.
Step Expected: The track data is stored securely in the database and associated with the correct patient.

Test Case Title: As a Clinician, I want to store classes so that patient care plans can be comprehensive.
Step Action: The system is running and the clinician is logged in. | The clinician creates a new class or updates an existing class.
Step Expected: The system stores the class details in the database.

Test Case Title: As a Clinician, I want to link patients to classes so that I can manage patient schedules and track their progress in relevant programs.
Step Action: I am a clinician with appropriate privileges. | I am viewing a patient's record or a class schedule.
Step Expected: I can easily link the patient to the class.

Test Case Title: As a Nurse, I want to store schedules, so that I can manage patient appointments and staff availability.
Step Action: I am logged in as a Nurse. | I enter the schedule information.
Step Expected: The system stores the schedule information in the database.

Test Case Title: As a Doctor, I want to access stored patient sessions so that I can review patient progress and adjust care plans.
Step Action: Patient data exists in the system | I request to view a patient's sessions
Step Expected: I should see a list of the patient's sessions, including date, time, and session details.

Test Case Title: As a user, I want to store all data associated with sessions so that the system maintains a complete record of patient activity and attendance.
Step Action: The user is interacting with the system | The system processes session-related data (e.g., attendance, schedules, modifications)
Step Expected: The system stores all relevant data associated with the session in the database.

Test Case Title: As a Doctor, I want to store group notes for sessions so that I can easily access and review session details.
Step Action: I am logged into the system and viewing a patient's session. | I enter group notes for the session.
Step Expected: The group notes are stored securely in the database and associated with the session.

Test Case Title: As a Doctor, I want to store individual notes for sessions, so that I can track patient progress and tailor treatment plans effectively.
Step Action: A session exists for a patient | I enter notes related to the session
Step Expected: The notes are stored securely and associated with that specific session and patient, adhering to HIPAA regulations.

Test Case Title: As a Doctor, I want to track reviews of care plans so that I can ensure quality of patient care.
Step Action: a care plan exists for a patient | a review is performed on the care plan
Step Expected: the system should track the review, including the reviewer and date of review

Test Case Title: As a Doctor, I want to view the Assessment timeline so that I can easily track patient progress.
Step Action: I am logged into the system as a Doctor and viewing a patient's record. | I navigate to the Assessments section.
Step Expected: I should see a clear and accurate timeline of the patient's assessments, including dates and key milestones.

Test Case Title: As a Clinician, I want to calculate who is billable based on dates, so that the billing process is streamlined and accurate.
Step Action: The system has patient data, session information, and billing rules. | I initiate the billability calculation process.
Step Expected: The system accurately identifies and displays which patients are billable based on the specified dates and billing rules.

Test Case Title: As a Clinician, I want to keep track of what claims have been sent for, so that I can efficiently manage billing and ensure accurate revenue cycle management.
Step Action: A patient session has occurred and a claim needs to be generated. | The claim is submitted for processing.
Step Expected: The system should record the details of the claim, including patient, service, date, and amount submitted.

Test Case Title: As a Doctor, I want to track the status of claims (accepted or denied) so that I can efficiently manage patient billing and revenue cycle.
Step Action: A claim has been submitted for a patient | The claim is accepted or denied by the insurance provider
Step Expected: The system should update the claim status to reflect the accepted or denied status.

Test Case Title: As a Doctor, I want to track the status of claims (accepted or denied) so that I can efficiently manage patient billing and revenue cycle.
Step Action: I am viewing a patient's billing information | I access the claims history
Step Expected: I should be able to see the status (accepted or denied) of each claim.

Test Case Title: As a system, I want to have stored procedures for calculations within the database so that calculations are efficient and consistent.
Step Action: The database is operational | A calculation is required
Step Expected: The system uses a stored procedure to perform the calculation

Test Case Title: As a system, I want to have stored procedures for calculations within the database so that calculations are efficient and consistent.
Step Action: A new calculation is needed | A developer creates a stored procedure
Step Expected: The stored procedure is stored in the database

Test Case Title: As a Clinician, I want to keep track of what claims have been sent for, so that I can ensure accurate billing and revenue cycle management.
Step Action: The system has session data and billing information. | I view a session or patient record.
Step Expected: I can see a clear indication of whether a claim has been submitted for the services provided.

Test Case Title: As a Clinician, I want to run a billing report so that I can track billing information.
Step Action: I am a Clinician and have access to the system. | I request a billing report.
Step Expected: The system generates a report containing billing information.

Test Case Title: As a user, I want to see a list of sessions in the Portal so that I can easily find and access the sessions I need.
Step Action: I am logged into the Portal. | I navigate to the sessions section.
Step Expected: I should see a list of all available sessions.

Test Case Title: As a Doctor, I want to view details of a particular session so that I can review patient progress and session specifics.
Step Action: I am logged in as a Doctor and viewing a list of sessions. | I select a particular session from the list.
Step Expected: I should be able to see more details about the selected session, including facilitator information, time and scheduling, attendance, and group/individual notes.

Test Case Title: As a Doctor, I want to view session information, so that I can review patient progress and make informed decisions about their care.
Step Action: I am logged into the system as a Doctor and have selected a specific session. | I view the session details
Step Expected: I should see the facilitator information, time and scheduling, attendance, and group and individual notes.

Test Case Title: As a Doctor, I want to see Group and Individual notes for a session so that I can understand the patient's progress and tailor treatment plans.
Step Action: I am viewing the details of a specific session in the Clinician Portal. | I navigate to the 'Notes' section.
Step Expected: I should see both Group and Individual notes recorded for that session.

Test Case Title: As a Nurse, I want to enter and view patient assessments, so that I can effectively manage patient care and track progress.
Step Action: I am logged into the system as a Nurse. | I navigate to a patient's profile.
Step Expected: I can enter new assessment data for Nursing, Nutrition, Health Literacy, Care Management, and Behavioral aspects.

Test Case Title: As a Nurse, I want to enter and view patient assessments, so that I can effectively manage patient care and track progress.
Step Action: I am viewing a patient's profile. | I access the 'Assessments' section.
Step Expected: I can view all previously recorded assessments for the patient.

Test Case Title: As a Doctor, I want to view patient assessments including Nursing, Nutrition, Health Literacy, Care Management, and Behavioral Health, so that I can make informed decisions about patient care.
Step Action: I am logged in as a Doctor and viewing a patient's record. | I navigate to the 'Assessments' section.
Step Expected: I can see assessments related to Nursing, Nutrition, Health Literacy, Care Management, and Behavioral Health.

Test Case Title: As a Nurse, I want to enter and view patient assessments (Nursing, Nutrition, Health Literacy, Care Management, Behavioral) so that I can effectively conduct the Care-plan process.
Step Action: I am logged into the system as a Nurse. | I access a patient's record.
Step Expected: I can view existing assessments (Nursing, Nutrition, Health Literacy, Care Management, Behavioral).

Test Case Title: As a Nurse, I want to enter and view patient assessments (Nursing, Nutrition, Health Literacy, Care Management, Behavioral) so that I can effectively conduct the Care-plan process.
Step Action: I am logged into the system as a Nurse. | I access a patient's record and navigate to the assessments section.
Step Expected: I can enter new assessment data (Nursing, Nutrition, Health Literacy, Care Management, Behavioral).

Test Case Title: As a Clinician, I want to perform care plan review so that I can ensure the patient's care plan is up-to-date and effective.
Step Action: I am logged in as a Clinician and viewing a patient's record. | I initiate a care plan review.
Step Expected: I can access and review the patient's current care plan details.

Test Case Title: As a Clinician, I want to view a patient's care plan history, so that I can track changes and understand the patient's treatment progression.
Step Action: A patient has one or more care plans recorded in the system | I navigate to the patient's record and select the option to view care plan history
Step Expected: I should see a chronological list of all care plans for that patient, including the dates they were active.

Test Case Title: As a Clinician, I want to view a patient's care plan history, so that I can track changes and understand the patient's treatment progression.
Step Action: I am viewing the care plan history | I select a specific care plan from the history
Step Expected: I should be able to view the details of that care plan as it existed at that point in time.

Test Case Title: As a Clinician, I want to make updates or changes to a Care Plan, so that the patient's care plan is current and accurate.
Step Action: A Care Plan exists for a patient | I make updates or changes to the Care Plan
Step Expected: The system saves the updated Care Plan with the changes.

Test Case Title: As a system administrator, I want the system to audit all data changes, so that I can track data modifications for compliance and security purposes.
Step Action: The system is running and a user modifies patient data or documents. | A user adds, changes, or deletes data.
Step Expected: The system should record the user's identity, the timestamp of the action, the type of action (add, change, delete), and the specific data that was modified.

Test Case Title: As a system administrator, I want the system to audit all data changes, so that I can track data modifications for compliance and security purposes.
Step Action: I need to review the audit history. | I request an audit report for a specific user or patient.
Step Expected: The system should generate a report displaying the audit history, including user, timestamp, action, and data modified.

Test Case Title: As a system administrator, I want the system to audit all data changes, so that I can track data modifications for compliance and security purposes.
Step Action: I need to export the audit history. | I request to export the audit history.
Step Expected: The system should export the audit history in a standard format (e.g., CSV, Excel) for external analysis.

Test Case Title: As a Doctor, I want the system to track the addition of new documents to a patient's EHR, so that I can maintain an accurate and auditable record of patient information.
Step Action: A doctor adds a new document to a patient's EHR | The document is saved in the system
Step Expected: The system should record the addition of the document, including the user who added it and the timestamp of the addition.

Test Case Title: As a Facilitator, I want to override the patient sign out for the session, so that I can manage patient sessions effectively.
Step Action: A patient is signed in for a session | I, as a Facilitator, override the patient sign out
Step Expected: The system should record the override action, including the facilitator's identity and timestamp.

Test Case Title: As a Clinician, I want the system to track deletions of existing documents or data, so that there is an audit trail for data integrity and compliance.
Step Action: I am a clinician and I delete a patient document. | I confirm the deletion.
Step Expected: The system records the deletion event, including the user, timestamp, and document details, in the audit log.

Test Case Title: As a Doctor, I want to view reports showing auditing history per patient so that I can monitor changes to patient data and ensure data integrity.
Step Action: I am logged in as a Doctor. | I navigate to the patient's record.
Step Expected: I can view a report displaying the audit history for that patient, including additions, changes, and deletions of documents and data.

Test Case Title: As a Clinician, I want to view the audit history of a document so that I can track changes and ensure data integrity.
Step Action: I am logged in as a Clinician and viewing a patient's document | I select the option to view audit history
Step Expected: I should see a detailed log of all additions, changes, and deletions made to the document, including the user who made the change and the timestamp.

Test Case Title: As a Clinician, I want to view the audit history of a document so that I can track changes and ensure data integrity.
Step Action: I am viewing the audit history of a document | I request to export the audit history
Step Expected: The audit history should be exported in a standard format (e.g., CSV, PDF) that can be easily reviewed and shared, as per requirement 2.3.3.16.

Test Case Title: As a Doctor, I want to clearly see the link between patient goals and sessions, so that I can better understand the patient's progress and tailor treatment plans accordingly.
Step Action: A patient has defined goals and is participating in sessions. | I view the patient's session details in the portal.
Step Expected: I can clearly see how the session relates to the patient's defined goals.

Test Case Title: As a Facilitator, I want to confirm session attendance taken through fingerprint scanner, so that I can ensure accurate attendance records.
Step Action: I am a Facilitator with read access to session attendance data. | I access the system to review session attendance.
Step Expected: I can confirm the attendance records taken through the fingerprint scanner.

Test Case Title: As a Clinician, I want to have read access to all documents and write access upon creation or special cases, so that I can view, interpret, create, and add new documents for patient care.
Step Action: I am logged in as a Clinician. | I attempt to access a patient document.
Step Expected: I should be able to view the document.

Test Case Title: As a Clinician, I want to have read access to all documents and write access upon creation or special cases, so that I can view, interpret, create, and add new documents for patient care.
Step Action: I am logged in as a Clinician. | I create a new patient document.
Step Expected: I should be able to save the document.

Test Case Title: As a Clinician, I want to have read access to all documents and write access upon creation or special cases, so that I can view, interpret, create, and add new documents for patient care.
Step Action: I am logged in as a Clinician. | A special case allows me write access to an existing document.
Step Expected: I should be able to modify and save the document.

Test Case Title: As a System Administrator, I want database schema documentation and a guide for running the database setup script, so that I can properly set up and maintain the database.
Step Action: I am a System Administrator responsible for database setup and maintenance. | I access the user documentation.
Step Expected: I can view the complete database schema.

Test Case Title: As a System Administrator, I want database schema documentation and a guide for running the database setup script, so that I can properly set up and maintain the database.
Step Action: I am a System Administrator responsible for database setup and maintenance. | I access the user documentation.
Step Expected: I can follow a step-by-step guide to run the database setup script successfully.

Test Case Title: As a Doctor, Nurse, or Patient, I want tutorial documentation within the application so that I can easily learn how to use the system and understand proper protocols.
Step Action: I am a new user of the application. | I access a feature for the first time.
Step Expected: I am presented with step-by-step instructions, screenshots, and in-application tooltips to guide me through the process.

Test Case Title: As a Doctor, Nurse, or Patient, I want tutorial documentation within the application so that I can easily learn how to use the system and understand proper protocols.
Step Action: I need to understand a specific procedure within the application. | I access the tutorial documentation.
Step Expected: I can find clear explanations of the procedure, including legal and business concerns.

Test Case Title: As a facilitator, I want clear navigation and tooltips in the session application so that I can easily verify attendance, record notes, and understand the application's functionality.
Step Action: I am a new facilitator using the session application | I navigate through the application
Step Expected: I can easily understand the purpose of each section and function due to clear navigation and helpful tooltips.

Test Case Title: As a Doctor, I want to view patient assessments and care plans within the system, so that I can efficiently review patient data and provide appropriate care.
Step Action: I am a Doctor with access to the system. | I select a patient record.
Step Expected: I can view the patient's assessments and care plans in a digitized format.

Test Case Title: As a Doctor, I want to quickly access patient information through the Clinician Portal so that I can efficiently review patient data and make informed decisions.
Step Action: I am logged into the Clinician Portal. | I request to view a patient's information.
Step Expected: The patient's information is displayed in a user-friendly and easily navigable interface.

Test Case Title: As a Facilitator, I want to confirm session attendance taken through fingerprint scanner, so that I can ensure accurate attendance records.
Step Action: the session application is running and connected to the fingerprint scanner | I access the session attendance records
Step Expected: I can view and confirm the attendance data captured by the fingerprint scanner.

Test Case Title: As a Clinician Portal user, I want the application to respond quickly, so that I can efficiently access and modify patient information.
Step Action: I am a user accessing the Clinician Portal. | I navigate to a page within the application.
Step Expected: The page should load in under 2 seconds.

Test Case Title: As a Clinician Portal user, I want the application to respond quickly, so that I can efficiently access and modify patient information.
Step Action: I am a user accessing the Clinician Portal. | I navigate to a page within the application.
Step Expected: On average, the page should load in under 0.5 seconds.

Test Case Title: As a Clinician Portal user, I want the application to respond quickly, so that I can efficiently access and modify patient information.
Step Action: I am a user accessing the Clinician Portal. | I navigate to a page within the application.
Step Expected: The page should never take more than 5 seconds to load.

Test Case Title: As a Doctor, I want the Clinician Portal to load quickly, so that I can efficiently review patient data.
Step Action: I am a Doctor using the Clinician Portal | I access a page within the portal
Step Expected: the page loads in under 2 seconds

Test Case Title: As a Doctor, I want the Clinician Portal to load quickly, so that I can efficiently review patient data.
Step Action: I am a Doctor using the Clinician Portal | I access a page within the portal
Step Expected: on average, the page loads in under 0.5 seconds

Test Case Title: As a Doctor, I want database queries to execute quickly, so that I can efficiently access patient information and make timely decisions.
Step Action: the system has fewer than 25 active database connections | I execute a database query
Step Expected: the query returns results in less than 10 seconds

Test Case Title: As a Doctor, I want the Clinician Portal pages to load quickly, so that I can efficiently review patient data.
Step Action: I am a Doctor using the Clinician Portal | I access a page within the portal
Step Expected: the page loads in under 5 seconds

Test Case Title: As a Doctor, I want the Clinician Portal to load quickly, so that I can efficiently review patient data.
Step Action: I am a Doctor accessing the Clinician Portal | I navigate to a page within the portal
Step Expected: the page loads in under 2 seconds on average.

Test Case Title: As a Doctor, I want the clinician portal to be accessible 99.9% of the time during business hours, so that I can reliably access patient data when needed.
Step Action: The clinician portal is deployed and running | I attempt to access the portal during business hours
Step Expected: The portal is accessible 99.9% of the time

Test Case Title: As a Clinician, I want the system to audit document and data changes so that I can track modifications and maintain data integrity.
Step Action: I am a clinician using the portal | I add, modify, or delete a document or data
Step Expected: the system should track the addition, change, or deletion, including user and timestamp.

Test Case Title: As a Clinician, I want the system to audit document and data changes so that I can track modifications and maintain data integrity.
Step Action: I am a clinician using the portal | I request an audit report
Step Expected: the system should generate a report showing the auditing history, either per user or per patient.

Test Case Title: As a Clinician, I want the system to audit document and data changes so that I can track modifications and maintain data integrity.
Step Action: I am a clinician using the portal | I request to export an auditing history
Step Expected: the system should allow me to export the auditing history.

Test Case Title: As a Clinician, I want fingerprint scanning to return results quickly, so that I can efficiently access the system.
Step Action: the clinician is using the fingerprint scanner | the clinician initiates a fingerprint scan
Step Expected: the system returns results within 1 second

Test Case Title: As a Clinician Application, I want to ensure patient information is only accessible to authorized users, so that patient privacy is maintained and HIPAA regulations are met.
Step Action: A user attempts to access patient information | The user is not authorized to view the patient's information
Step Expected: The application will prevent the user from accessing the information.

Test Case Title: As a System Administrator, I want the database to be encrypted at rest so that patient data is protected and compliant with HIPAA.
Step Action: The system is deployed and running | Data is stored in the database
Step Expected: The database is encrypted at rest.

Test Case Title: As a Clinician Portal User, I want all data transfers to be secured with SSL, so that patient data is protected during transmission.
Step Action: I am using the Clinician Portal. | I am accessing or modifying patient information.
Step Expected: All data transferred between the server and my application will be done over SSL.

Test Case Title: As a System Administrator, I want the database to only be accessible by devices on the same network so that unauthorized access to sensitive patient data is prevented.
Step Action: The database server is running | A connection is attempted from a device outside the network
Step Expected: The connection is rejected

Test Case Title: As a System Administrator, I want the database to only be accessible by devices on the same network so that unauthorized access to sensitive patient data is prevented.
Step Action: The database server is running | A connection is attempted from a device within the same network
Step Expected: The connection is established

Test Case Title: As a Doctor, I want all communication between the server and Clinician Application to be done over SSL, so that patient data is transmitted securely and complies with HIPAA.
Step Action: I am a Doctor using the Clinician Application. | I access or modify patient information.
Step Expected: All communication between the Clinician Application and the server is encrypted using SSL.

Test Case Title: As a Session App User, I want all patient information stored locally on the computer to be encrypted so that patient data is protected and compliant with HIPAA.
Step Action: The Session App is running on a computer. | Patient information is stored locally on the computer.
Step Expected: The patient information is encrypted.

Test Case Title: As a Session App, I want all communication with the server to be done over SSL so that patient information stored locally is secure.
Step Action: The Session App is communicating with the server | Data is being transmitted between the Session App and the server
Step Expected: The communication must be encrypted using SSL

Test Case Title: As a Doctor, I want the Clinician Application to have a high aesthetic rating so that I find it visually appealing and easy to use.
Step Action: the Doctor is using the Clinician Application | they interact with the user interface
Step Expected: the application's aesthetics should be rated at ⅘ or above by at least 85% of clinicians.

Test Case Title: As a Doctor, I want the Clinician application to be easy to use so that I can efficiently review patient data and improve patient care.
Step Action: I am a Doctor using the Clinician application. | I am performing common tasks such as reviewing patient data, updating notes, and ordering tests.
Step Expected: The application should be intuitive and easy to navigate, allowing me to complete tasks quickly and efficiently.

Test Case Title: As a Doctor, I want the Clinician application to be easy to use so that I can efficiently review patient data and improve patient care.
Step Action: A survey is conducted with clinicians after using the application. | Clinicians are asked to rate the application's ease of use.
Step Expected: At least 80% of clinicians should rate the application at ⅘ or above for ease of use.

Test Case Title: As a Doctor, I want the Clinician application to be easy to learn so that I can quickly access and interpret patient data.
Step Action: I am a Doctor using the Clinician application. | I am learning to use the application.
Step Expected: The application should be intuitive and easy to understand, allowing me to quickly become proficient.

Test Case Title: As a Doctor, I want the Clinician application to be easy to learn so that I can quickly access and interpret patient data.
Step Action: We survey Doctors on their experience with the Clinician application. | 90% of Doctors rate the application at 4/5 or above for ease of learning.
Step Expected: The application meets the ease of learning requirement.

Test Case Title: As a Facilitator, I want the Session App to have an appealing aesthetic so that I can effectively engage users during sessions.
Step Action: the facilitator is using the Session App | they are interacting with the user interface
Step Expected: the app's aesthetics should be rated at 4/5 or above by at least 85% of facilitators.

Test Case Title: As a Nurse, I want to be able to easily add and modify patient data, so that I can accurately maintain patient records.
Step Action: I am a nurse logged into the system. | I add or modify patient data.
Step Expected: The system should allow me to do so easily and efficiently.

Test Case Title: As a Nurse, I want to be able to easily add and modify patient data, so that I can accurately maintain patient records.
Step Action: I am a nurse. | I add, modify, or delete patient data.
Step Expected: The system should track these changes for auditing purposes, including user, timestamp, and specific data changed.

Test Case Title: As a Facilitator, I want the Session App to be easy to learn so that I can quickly and effectively use it to manage sessions.
Step Action: The facilitator is a new user of the Session App. | The facilitator completes the initial training and uses the app for a few sessions.
Step Expected: The facilitator rates the Session App at 4/5 or above for ease of learning.

Test Case Title: As a Facilitator, I want the Session App to be easy to learn so that I can quickly and effectively use it to manage sessions.
Step Action: A survey is conducted among facilitators after using the Session App. | The survey results are analyzed.
Step Expected: At least 90% of facilitators rate the Session App at 4/5 or above for ease of learning.

Test Case Title: As a Doctor, I want to access patient information through a web-based Clinician Portal, so that I can efficiently review patient data and modify information in the database.
